posts.author: HipMaestro
posts.content:
"Fixed" can be subjective depending on the designer.

Each seem to have interpreted the spell's "intent" differently according to the balance sought, though there appears to be a standard dynamic on many servers.

For example, one server I've played stops the entire venturing party within range except caster (along with all hostiles in the vicinity, of course) yet doesn't affect any summoned creatures. Whether that was an intentional side-effect or just a best-case-compromise type fix, I wouldn't know. But that server was operating that way for at least 5 years that I can recall. The effective range of effect allows any artillery attacker outside the range of the effect of the TS caster to attack all those within its effect with impunity. But once again, that is the way the spell was scripted on that one server. I suspect the range of effect is the problem scripting the spell, deciding what range make the most sense and produces the least lag. It can't be infinite or it would produce a real can of worms. Imagine what happens when 50 PCs are running around spamming Timestops on the same server, especially if items are provided that contain that spell property.

I imagine that the server freeze problem would have been eliminated on any of contemporary well-managed servers today. For PW managers new to the craft, however, who knows how they have it working?

I'll go you one further. Suppose an environment built their uber bosses so that it would be impossible to kill them by any means OTHER than using Timestop. You need not suppose too long because they are out there.

There are varying degrees of "cheapness" throughout NWN any of which which can render a sound build strategy as ineffective.

I am guessing that is why Timestop was set to 9 sec duration just like True Strike, another easily exploitable spell. The game originators could anticipate the potential even then. Take notice that throughout all the patching, both these spells have remained more-or-less the same as when they were conceived. Eliminating the somatic component of Timestop post-v1.66 made it even more useful for armored arcanists than before. Gotta scratch my head on why Bioware made that change.

What I find most interesting is that PW designers seeking to balance their environment, rather than get involved making massive adjustments to balance factors like Timestop, simply eliminate them. IMO that is a cheap solution that requires no imagination or creativity. It's easy to get out a cleaver and start hacking out all the aspects of the game that seem inappropriate. What remains when they do that, however, is a pale version of the original game. For some, it must seem a reasonable tact, because many of those hacked-apart servers still have significant number of regular subscribers. I also suspect there were many ppl who never really like the original game and its dynamics so migrated to those pseudo-NWN servers when they changed the game so drastically.

IMHO you are appalled to the degree you are because clerics have no recourse against it as hard as they pray to their chosen deity to save them from it!

BTW, morons cannot Timestop. They require high intelligence (well, at least 19, anyways)... except those half-orc UMDers who find a TS scroll laying around and wonder "Wut dis thing do?". UMD, another cheapness exploitable aspect limited to only a select few classes.
